title: Kelud (Kelut)
meta_title: Kelud Volcano — Eruption History, Crater Lake & Facts | VolcanoAtlas
meta_description: Kelud (Kelut) is a 1,730 m active stratovolcano in East Java, Indonesia. Famous for deadly crater lake eruptions. Full history from 1000 CE to 2014.

quick_answer.what: Kelud (also spelled Kelut) is an active stratovolcano rising to 1,730 m (5,676 ft) in East Java, Indonesia, infamous for its explosive crater-lake eruptions that rank among the deadliest in Indonesian history.
quick_answer.status: Active — last erupted in February 2014 (VEI 4). The volcano has produced more than 30 eruptions since 1000 CE.
quick_answer.famous_for: Its summit crater lake, which superheats before eruptions and is violently ejected as scalding lahars. The 1919 eruption killed over 5,000 people.
quick_answer.danger_level: Very high — over 5 million people live within 30 km, and the volcano's lahar-generating eruption style makes it one of the deadliest in Indonesia's history.

key_facts_box.tectonic_setting: Subduction zone — Indo-Australian Plate beneath Eurasian Plate (continental crust > 25 km)
key_facts_box.nearest_city: Kediri — ~26 km west; Blitar — ~22 km south
key_facts_box.crater_lake: Intermittently present; repeatedly destroyed and reformed by eruptions
key_facts_box.monitoring_agency: PVMBG (Pusat Vulkanologi dan Mitigasi Bencana Geologi)

overview.content: Kelud (also commonly spelled Kelut) is an active stratovolcano rising to 1,730 m (5,676 ft) in East Java, Indonesia, approximately 90 km southwest of Surabaya, the country's second-largest city. Despite its relatively inconspicuous profile, Kelud ranks among the most dangerous and historically deadly volcanoes in Indonesia, having killed more than 15,000 people across its recorded eruption history. The volcano's notoriety derives from its summit crater lake, which has repeatedly served as the source of catastrophic lahars when eruptions violently eject millions of cubic meters of superheated water. More than 30 eruptions have been documented since 1000 CE, and the volcano has produced at least 6 events at VEI 4 or higher, including a VEI 5 eruption in 1586. The combination of violent, short-duration eruptions, lahar-prone topography, and a densely populated surrounding landscape — over 5 million people live within 30 km — makes Kelud one of Indonesia's highest-priority volcanoes for monitoring and hazard mitigation. The volcano's eruption history has directly shaped Indonesian volcanic engineering, prompting the construction of drainage tunnels to reduce the crater lake's volume — a pioneering effort in volcanic risk reduction. Kelud's most recent eruption in February 2014 produced a VEI 4 event that sent ash as far as Surabaya and Yogyakarta, grounded flights across Java, and demonstrated that the volcano remains a formidable threat despite engineering interventions.

geology_and_formation.content: Kelud sits on the Sunda Volcanic Arc, generated by the northward subduction of the Indo-Australian Plate beneath the Eurasian Plate at approximately 6–7 cm per year. The volcano rises from the thick continental crust (>25 km) of the East Java back-arc region, producing andesitic to basaltic-andesitic magma that fuels its characteristically explosive eruptions. The summit complex consists of a cluster of lava domes cut by numerous craters, giving the upper edifice an irregular, rugged profile. Eruptive activity has migrated in a broadly clockwise direction around the summit vent complex over time, creating overlapping crater structures. Satellitic cones and lava domes also occur on the eastern, western, and south-southwest flanks. The volcano's most consequential geological feature has been its summit crater lake, which forms in the depression created by explosive eruptions and then serves as the raw material for devastating lahars during subsequent events. The interplay between magma, water, and steep topography is what makes Kelud so dangerous: phreatomagmatic explosions — triggered by the interaction of rising magma with the lake — instantaneously convert millions of cubic meters of water into superheated steam and scalding mudflows.

eruption_history_overview.content: Kelud has produced at least 40 recorded eruptions dating back to approximately 230 BCE, with detailed historical records from 1000 CE onward. The volcano erupts in characteristically short, violent paroxysms rather than prolonged effusive episodes, often reaching peak intensity within hours and subsiding within days. At least 12 eruptions have reached VEI 3 or higher, and the volcano has generated multiple VEI 4 events (1641, 1826, 1919, 1951, 1966, 1990, and 2014) plus one VEI 5 (1586). The recurrence interval between major eruptions has historically averaged 15–30 years in the modern period, though clusters of activity have occurred. The cumulative death toll from Kelud's eruptions exceeds 15,000, primarily from lahars, making it one of the deadliest volcanoes in recorded history.

subsections.title: The 1586 Eruption — VEI 5 Catastrophe
subsections.content: The 1586 eruption of Kelud was the largest in its recorded history, rated VEI 5. Historical Javanese sources describe massive destruction across the surrounding region. Though death toll estimates vary, some accounts suggest as many as 10,000 people were killed — primarily by lahars generated from the explosive ejection of the crater lake and by pyroclastic flows sweeping down the volcano's flanks. This eruption demonstrated the catastrophic potential of large-volume phreatomagmatic events at crater-lake volcanoes.

subsections.title: The 1919 Eruption — 5,110 Killed by Lahars
subsections.content: The May 19, 1919 eruption is the most devastating event in Kelud's modern history and one of the deadliest volcanic disasters of the 20th century. Rated VEI 4, the eruption violently expelled the crater lake — estimated at approximately 40 million cubic meters of water — generating massive hot lahars that swept down river valleys at terrifying speed. The mudflows destroyed entire villages and killed 5,110 people, most within the river valleys draining the volcano. The catastrophe prompted the Dutch colonial government to commission drainage tunnels bored through the crater wall to permanently lower the lake level by more than 50 m.

subsections.title: The 1951 Eruption — Engineering Tested
subsections.content: The 1951 eruption (VEI 4) provided the first test of the Dutch-built drainage tunnels. While the tunnels had successfully reduced the lake level, the eruption was powerful enough to deepen the crater by 70 m, altering the drainage geometry. Seven people were killed — a dramatic reduction from 1919, though the tunnels were damaged and required extensive repair. After restoration, the lake refilled to approximately 50 million cubic meters.

subsections.title: The 1966 Eruption — 200 Deaths Despite Precautions
subsections.content: Despite the drainage system, the 1966 eruption (VEI 4) killed more than 200 people, primarily from lahars. The eruption demonstrated that even reduced lake volumes could still generate deadly flows when combined with violent explosive ejection. In response, a new, deeper drainage tunnel was constructed, reducing the lake volume to approximately 1 million cubic meters prior to the 1990 eruption.

subsections.title: The 2014 Eruption — VEI 4 Explosive Paroxysm
subsections.content: On February 13, 2014, Kelud erupted with little warning in a powerful VEI 4 event that lasted only a few hours but had enormous impact. Unlike previous eruptions, the crater lake had been largely displaced by a lava dome that grew during a 2007 eruption, so lahars were not the primary hazard. Instead, the 2014 eruption was a massive explosive event: a Plinian column rose to approximately 17 km (56,000 ft) altitude, spreading ash across Java from Surabaya to Yogyakarta — a distance of over 200 km. Seven international airports were temporarily closed. At least 7 people were killed, and over 100,000 were evacuated. The eruption completely destroyed the 2007 lava dome and reshaped the summit crater.

current_status_and_monitoring.content: Since the 2014 eruption, Kelud has been in a state of relative quiescence, with the summit crater gradually refilling with water. PVMBG monitors the volcano through seismic networks, GPS deformation measurements, gas sampling, and regular visual observations. The crater lake temperature and water level are tracked as key precursory indicators, since rising lake temperatures have historically preceded eruptions by weeks to months. The volcano's alert level remains at Normal (Level I) during quiescent periods but can be rapidly escalated. Given Kelud's average recurrence interval of approximately 15–30 years between major eruptions, volcanologists are monitoring closely for signs of magmatic recharge.

hazards_and_risk_assessment.content: Kelud's hazard profile is dominated by lahars, though the 2014 eruption demonstrated that explosive ash columns can be equally destructive. The volcano's dense population base — more than 5 million people within 30 km, including the cities of Kediri (~320,000) and Blitar (~150,000) — places enormous numbers of people at risk. River valleys draining the volcano act as channels for lahars that can travel tens of kilometers in minutes. The engineering response — drainage tunnels to reduce crater lake volume — has been partially effective but cannot eliminate the hazard entirely. PVMBG maintains exclusion zones and evacuation plans, but the logistical challenge of moving hundreds of thousands of people on short notice remains the central problem in Kelud risk management.

geography_and_physical_description.content: Kelud rises in the agricultural heartland of East Java, surrounded by rice paddies, sugarcane fields, and fruit orchards that benefit from the extraordinarily fertile volcanic soils. The summit is relatively inconspicuous compared to Java's more imposing stratovolcanoes — the irregular cluster of domes and craters lacks the classic conical silhouette of nearby Semeru or Merapi. Multiple river valleys radiate outward from the summit, providing natural conduits for lahars. The crater lake, when present, occupies a shallow depression at the summit and has varied dramatically in size and depth following each eruption.

cultural_significance.content: Kelud holds a significant place in Javanese culture and history. Ancient Javanese texts reference the volcano's eruptions, and the name Kelud (or Kelut) derives from the Javanese word for 'swept,' referencing the devastating lahars that sweep clean the river valleys below. The volcanic soils around Kelud support some of the most productive agricultural land in Java, creating a paradox common to volcanic regions: the same force that periodically destroys also sustains the livelihoods of millions. The 1919 disaster and the subsequent Dutch engineering response represent a landmark in the history of volcanic hazard mitigation worldwide — one of the first large-scale attempts to physically alter a volcano's structure to reduce risk.

nearby_volcanoes.content: Kelud is one of dozens of active volcanoes along the Java segment of the Sunda Volcanic Arc. Notable neighbors include Semeru (3,657 m), Java's highest volcano approximately 80 km to the east, and Arjuno-Welirang to the north. The broader East Java volcanic region also includes Bromo (part of the Tengger caldera complex) and the Ijen crater lake. Farther west along the arc lie Merapi and Krakatau, together constituting one of the densest concentrations of active volcanoes in the world within Indonesia.

Explosive paroxysm, ash across Java, 7 killed

facts: Kelud has killed more than 15,000 people across its recorded eruption history, making it one of the deadliest volcanoes in Indonesia.
The 1919 eruption expelled approximately 40 million cubic meters of crater lake water as scalding lahars, killing 5,110 people.
Dutch colonial engineers bored drainage tunnels through the crater wall after 1919, lowering the lake by over 50 m — one of the world's first volcanic engineering projects.
The 2014 eruption sent a Plinian ash column to approximately 17 km (56,000 ft) altitude, closing 7 airports across Java.
The name Kelud (Kelut) derives from the Javanese word meaning 'swept,' referring to the lahars that sweep valleys clean during eruptions.
Over 5 million people live within 30 km of the summit, making it one of the most densely surrounded active volcanoes in the world.
The 1951 eruption deepened the crater by 70 m in a single event, fundamentally altering the drainage tunnel geometry.
Kelud's eruptions are characteristically short and violent — the 2014 VEI 4 eruption lasted only a few hours from onset to cessation.
A lava dome that grew in the crater during a 2007 eruption displaced much of the lake, changing the eruption hazard from lahar-dominated to ash-dominated for the 2014 event.
The volcano has produced at least 6 eruptions rated VEI 4 or higher since 1641, with a single VEI 5 in 1586.

faqs.question: Is Kelud volcano still active?
faqs.answer: Yes, Kelud is classified as an active volcano. Its most recent eruption occurred on February 13, 2014, when a powerful VEI 4 explosive event sent ash across much of Java and closed seven airports. The volcano has produced more than 30 eruptions since 1000 CE and averages a major eruption every 15–30 years. PVMBG monitors Kelud continuously, tracking crater lake temperature and seismicity as key precursory indicators. Volcanologists consider future eruptions certain.

faqs.question: How many people has Kelud killed?
faqs.answer: Kelud has killed more than 15,000 people across its recorded eruption history, making it one of Indonesia's deadliest volcanoes. The worst single event was the 1919 eruption, which killed 5,110 people through lahars generated by the explosive ejection of the crater lake. The 1586 VEI 5 eruption may have killed as many as 10,000. Other deadly events include 1966 (200+ deaths) and 1951 (7 deaths). The declining death toll partly reflects engineering interventions and improved early warning systems.

faqs.question: What makes Kelud's eruptions so deadly?
faqs.answer: Kelud's lethality stems from the interaction between its explosive eruptions and the summit crater lake. When magma rises into the lake, it triggers phreatomagmatic explosions that instantaneously convert millions of cubic meters of water into superheated steam and scalding mudflows (lahars). These lahars race down river valleys at high speed, reaching populated lowlands kilometers away within minutes. The dense population base — over 5 million within 30 km — compounds the risk enormously.

faqs.question: What happened in Kelud's 2014 eruption?
faqs.answer: On February 13, 2014, Kelud erupted in a VEI 4 explosive paroxysm that lasted only a few hours. A Plinian column rose to approximately 17 km (56,000 ft), spreading ash across Java from Surabaya to Yogyakarta. Seven international airports were closed, over 100,000 people were evacuated, and at least 7 people were killed. Unlike previous eruptions, lahars were not the primary hazard because a lava dome had displaced much of the crater lake. The eruption completely destroyed that dome.

faqs.question: How tall is Kelud volcano?
faqs.answer: Kelud stands at 1,730 m (5,676 ft) above sea level. This is relatively modest compared to other major Javanese volcanoes: Semeru reaches 3,657 m and Merapi 2,910 m. Kelud's relatively low profile belies its explosive power — its eruptions are driven by the violent interaction of magma with the crater lake rather than by the height of the volcanic edifice.

faqs.question: What are the drainage tunnels at Kelud?
faqs.answer: Following the 1919 eruption that killed 5,110 people, Dutch colonial engineers constructed drainage tunnels through the crater wall to permanently lower the crater lake level by over 50 m, reducing the volume of water available for lahar generation. This was one of the world's first large-scale volcanic engineering projects. Additional deeper tunnels were built after subsequent eruptions in 1951 and 1966. While the tunnels have reduced casualties, they cannot eliminate the hazard entirely.

faqs.question: When will Kelud erupt next?
faqs.answer: No one can predict the exact timing of Kelud's next eruption, but the volcano's average recurrence interval of 15–30 years between major eruptions suggests another event is possible within the coming decades. The crater lake is gradually refilling since the 2014 eruption, slowly restoring the conditions for the lahar-generating eruption style that has made the volcano so deadly. PVMBG monitors crater lake temperature, seismicity, and ground deformation for signs of magmatic recharge.

schema_data.name: Kelud
schema_data.description: Active stratovolcano in East Java, Indonesia, infamous for deadly crater-lake eruptions that have killed over 15,000 people
